1. Henry Wise said, "There is no country," to urge an action taken at this place, which was followed by General Order No. 9 and a later meeting at Bennett Place. Ely Parker was told, "I'm glad to see one real American here," at a house in this place to which Wilmer McLean had moved four years prior. An army aiming to retreat to North Carolina after the Battle of Five Forks was eventually trapped at this place two weeks after the (*) Petersburg Campaign ended. A president asked the Marine band to play "Dixie" after an event at this place, where the Army of Northern Virginia was disbanded days after the capture of Richmond. For 10 points, in what Virginia town did Ulysses Grant accept Robert E. Lee's surrender?
ANSWER: Appomattox [accept Appomattox County or Appomattox Court House or Battle of Appomattox Court House; prompt on McLean House until read; prompt on Virginia]
<Rohan Kher, History - American - Pre-1865> ~30076~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

2. This scientist theorized that fluids behave similarly at similar reduced temperatures and pressures based on his finding that the critical compressibility factor was three-eighths. When studying an equation named for this scientist with PV diagrams, vertical or horizontal lines connect points on isotherms in the Maxwell construction. The distance of closest approach between two hard spheres is this scientist's (*) radius, which he used to derive a cubic equation of state with the constants a and b. London dispersion forces and dipole-dipole interactions are examples of intermolecular forces named after this scientist. For 10 points, a modification of the ideal gas law was developed by what Dutch physicist?
ANSWER: Johannes Diderik van der Waals (The first clue refers to the principle of corresponding states.)
<Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~30794~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. An artist of ofu-ona patterns in this material, Olowe of Ise, inspired David Adjaye ("AD-jay") and Philip Freelon's design of upside-down trapezoids for the exterior of a Smithsonian museum. Medicine is built into "power figures" made of this material called nkondi. Symbols called ibol appear on Kuba ndop statues in this material. Strings are used to split this material and reveal a spirit's face in transformation artworks of the (*) Tlingit ("KLING-it") and Haida. Abstract faces on Fang artworks made of this material inspired the figures in Les Demoiselles d'Avignon ("lay duh-mwah-ZELL dah-veen-YON"). Artworks of this material portray spirits of animals like an eagle or orca stacked on top of each other. For 10 points, what common material for African masks is also used for totem poles?
ANSWER: wood [accept trees or tree trunks; accept cedar] (The lead-in refers to the National Museum of African American History and Culture.)

4. The Ramsey problem, which later yielded a second-best solution for monopoly pricing, was originally formulated to optimize these things. Peter Diamond and James Mirrlees found that these things need not alter production decisions. These things' economic incidence, which is independent from statutory incidence, depends on the elasticities of suppliers and consumers. One type of these things that can bring private marginal cost into equality with social marginal cost was described by (*) A. C. Pigou. They're not quotas, but infant industries benefit from a type of these things. The "wedge" caused by these things results in deadweight loss. For 10 points, name these government policies, exemplified by tariffs, that proportionally raise prices.
ANSWER: taxes [or taxation; accept tax rates; accept commodity taxes; accept tariffs until read; prompt on rates]

6. This quantity defines the threshold at which optimality is achieved by the Von Kármán ogive ("OH-gyve"), which is a special case of the Sears–Haack body. This quantity is calculated from the displacement of powder in a common classroom experiment involving the Kundt's tube. For an ideal gas, the square of this quantity equals the heat capacity ratio times R T. This quantity equals the negative-one-half power of the product of density (*) isentropic compressibility in the Newton–Laplace equation. The prefixes "hyper," "trans," and "super" describe flows in which this quantity is exceeded. This quantity is 343 meters per second in air. 7. Either butterfly wings or a shell representing this location adorn the back of a son of Tlaloc ("TLAH-lohk") and Chalchiuhtlicue ("chal-CHEWT-lee-kway") in many depictions. An animal thrown to this location either hits Meztli or, due to his cowardice, Tecciztecatl ("teh-KEEZ-teh-COTT-ul"), who may embody a figure in this location. According to another story, this location was created when Coyolxauhqui ("coh-YOHL-shau-kee") was (*) decapitated and had her head thrown away by Huitzilopochtli ("weet-see-loh-poach-tlee"). Quetzalcoatl ("KET-sull-koh-AH-tull") imprints a rabbit's image on this location in one story due to the animal's willingness to serve as food for the god. For 10 points, the Aztecs tracked the phases of what celestial object?
ANSWER: the Moon

8. A giant one of these structures along the A93 Perth-Blairgowrie ("blair‑GOW‑ree") Road, dating to the Battle of Culloden, is named for the town of Meikleour. The Sherman Rhinoceros was developed to destroy these structures in the bocage of Normandy following D-Day. The Midland style of these structures slopes towards heavy bullocks. To enforce a salt tax in India, British officials built a 1,100-mile-long "Great" one of these structures. In the 1607 Newton Rebellion, commoners tore down these (*) living structures to protest enclosure. British formal gardens once routinely included mazes made from these structures. For 10 points, name these closely-placed shrubs that are widely used as fences and barriers in the UK.
ANSWER: hedge [or hedgerows or hedgebank or Devon hedge or Cornish hedge; prompt on plants or shrubs or trees or bushes; before any of these terms are read, prompt on mazes or labyrinths or barriers or live fences or walls by asking "what were they made of?"]

An early use of this technology caused a diplomatic incident involving the crew of Japan's (*) Lucky Dragon 5. A major milestone for this technology occurred with a device nicknamed the Sausage used in Ivy Mike. Sakharov's Third Idea was a Russian implementation of the Teller-Ulam design for this technology. In a novel by this author, a man returns a woman’s pawned necklace after he sees her losing at roulette. This author argued that overly perfect female protagonists reinforce prejudice against women's education in "Silly Novels by Lady Novelists." A man created by this author befriends Gwendolen Harleth and moves to "the East" upon learning his mother was (*) Jewish. 11. A faction of these people who fought one conflict to its end was called the "bitter enders" and included Jopie Fourie. These people, who formed the Republic of Stellaland and the State of Goshen, won independence in the Sand River Convention. The term "commando" was first used to describe these people's infantry during land conflicts by the Great Fish River, which were led by men such as (*) Piet Retief ("PETE reh-TEEF"). Herbert Kitchener ordered infrastructure razed to defeat these people's guerrilla tactics. After their "Great Trek" north from the Cape Colony, these people formed the Transvaal and Orange Free State. For 10 points, what descendants of South Africa's Dutch settlers fought two wars against the British?

14. Borstein et al. 2024 rejects the hypothesis that evolution of this structure is a key innovation in cichlids. In certain fish, the first pair of branchial arches develops into this structure. VDJ recombination is a synapomorphy of the clade of vertebrates named for possessing this structure, which is analogous to rotifers' trophi. The morphology of this structure distinguishes teleosts from other fishes in Gnatho·stomata. (*) Moray eels have a second retractable instance of this structure, which is missing in hagfish and lampreys. This structure can feature the premaxilla and the mandible, which is the only independently movable part of the human skull. For 10 points, name this structure that enables chewing.
ANSWER: jaws [or pharyngeal jaws; accept lower jaws or upper jaws]

ANSWER: permanganate [accept potassium permanganate; accept MnO4-] [10e] Permanganate's central manganese atom has an oxidation state of plus this number, the number of electrons in the outermost shell of a halogen.

[10h] 8,000 people were stranded at this airport during Typhoon Jebi in 2018. This airport, built on an artificial island and designed by Renzo Piano, has sunk 38 feet since 1994.
ANSWER: Kansai International Airport

14. It's not criminal justice, but Cheuksin, a goddess of this domain, attacks intruders with 150 centimeter long hair. For 10 points each:
[10h] Name this domain that the Ainu believe is ruled by Rukar Kamuy. Christians claimed Crepitus was the Roman god of these locations that were adorned with images of Fortuna.
ANSWER: toilets [or latrines; accept bathrooms; accept outhouses; accept equivalents]
[10m] Koreans performed jesas ("jay-sahs") to Cheuksin when children or these objects fell into the toilet. In Greek myth, a man loses one of these objects while carrying a disguised goddess across the Anauros River.
ANSWER: shoes [or sandals] (Jason loses his sandal while carrying the disguised Hera.)
[10e] Those jesas involved Ttongtteok ("tohng-tuck"), whose name suggests it to be made of poop and this food. The kami Inari is depicted carrying a sack of this Asian staple food.
ANSWER: rice [accept gohan or meshi or kome or bosatsu or ine; accept rice cake]

[10e] Name this country whose annexation was solidified via the Compromise of 1850. This country's second president, Mirabeau Lamar, moved its capital to Austin.
ANSWER: Republic of Texas
[10m] This monarch of another short-lived country was deposed outside the ʻIolani Palace by American-backed revolutionaries. This monarch opposed a king's signing of the Bayonet Constitution.
ANSWER: Queen Liliʻuokalani [or Lydia Liliʻu Loloku Walania Kamakaʻeha]
[10h] The U.S. did not recognize this republic, which James Madison thought was part of the Louisiana Purchase. Fulwar Skipwith was the only governor of this republic, which was officially ceded by the Adams-Onís Treaty.
ANSWER: Republic of West Florida [reject "Florida"]

16. In this play, a man says that his father told him to order his wife around, before concluding "I took the opposite of [his] advice and I've been happy ever since." For 10 points each:
[10h] Name this play, whose second act features a couple getting cold feet on their wedding day. A man acting as a minister in this play says, "I've married over two hundred couples in my day. Do I believe in it? I don't know."
ANSWER: Our Town
[10m] This character in Our Town officiates the wedding of George and Emily in the second act. This man brings Emily back to relive her twelfth birthday after she dies in childbirth. 
ANSWER: the Stage Manager

[10h] Identify this physicist who is the alphabetically latter namesake of a class of non-abelian gauge theories that are the subject of an "existence and mass gap problem."
ANSWER: Yang Chen-Ning [or Chen-Ning Yang or C. N. Yang or Frank Yang or Yáng Zhénnìng; accept Yang-Mills theory]
[10m] This Chinese-American "First Lady of Physics" conducted the experiments that verified Lee and Yang's model of the weak interaction, but she was snubbed for their Nobel.
ANSWER: Wu Chien-Shiung [or Chien-Shiung Wu or C. S. Wu or Wú Jiànxióng]
[10e] Yang collaborated with Wu Tai-Tung to theorize an alternative to the "Dirac" type of these hypothetical particles that carry magnetic charge and contain north or south, but not both.
ANSWER: magnetic monopoles [accept Dirac monopoles or Wu-Yang monopoles]

ANSWER: formaldehyde [or CH2O or methanal]
